"""
o See also:
- It means in abcd order, i.e. alphabetical, so I can put it first in the list of topics :-)
- ChartingAndPlotting - For Charts::ECharts or Imager, i.e. for all things to do with images
- ChildProcesses
- CommandLineStuff - For Getopt::Type::Tiny
- CryptoStuff - For random stuff
- DataTraversal
- DataTypes
- DatesAndTimes
- EventStuff
- FeaturesAndPragmas - For a must-read document
- FileHandling - For Path::Class, Path::Class::Tiny, Path::Tiny
- HTTPHandling
- LocaleStuff
- ModuleBuilding
- ParallelProcessing
- QandA - For an article explaining Object-Oriented Programming
- PdfStuff - For html2pdf etc
- SwitchStatements - For Multi::Dispatch, Sub::MultiMethod
- TestingHelp - For Test::Script etc
- https://blogs.perl.org/users/robert_acock/2026/01/ready-set-compile-you-slow-camel.html
- https://theweeklychallenge.org/blog/serialisation-in-perl/ - Serialization of data to ram/disk

o App::CSVUtils:
- CLI utilities related to CSV
- https://metacpan.org/dist/App-CSVUtils 
- The module contains 64 scripts

o Cron::Toolkit:
- Quartz-compatible cron parser with unique extensions and over 400 tests
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Cron-Toolkit

o csv2sqlite:
- Import a CSV file into SQLite database. See App::SQLiteUtils
- https://metacpan.org/dist/App-SQLiteUtils
- The module contains 4 scripts

o Data::KSUID:
- KSUID are a globally unique identifier similar to UUIDs but designed to be naturally sorted by generation timestamp and to have representations that are easily postable across systems
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Data::KSUID

o Data::OptList::Object:
- Data::OptList, but object-oriented
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Data::OptList::Object

o Data::TOON:
- Complete Perl implementation of TOON (Token-Oriented Object Notation)
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Data-TOON

o Dev::Util:
- Base modules for Perl Development
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Dev-Util

o e:
- Beast mode unleashed
- https://metacpan.org/pod/e

o Email::Stuffer:
- A more casual approach to creating and sending Email:: emails
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Email::Stuffer

o ixchel:
- Automate various sys admin stuff
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Ixchel
- Contains about 50 modules

o Locale::Codes:
- A distribution of many modules to handle locale codes
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Locale-Codes

o Melian:
- Perl client to the Melian cache
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Melian
- More details in CachingStuff

o Net::Gotify:
- Gotify client for Perl
- https://gotify.net/
- I feel this may beome extremely popular

o Net::Server:
- Extensible, general Perl server engine
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Net-Server
- Has a massive amount of flexibility

o Number::Finance::Human:
- Human-readable numbers for accounting and finance
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Number-Finance-Human

o Object::InsideOut:
- Comprehensive inside-out object support module
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Object::InsideOut

o Object::InsideOut::Metadata:
- Introspection for Object::InsideOut classes
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Object::InsideOut::Metadata

o Path::Tiny:
- Provides methods like slurp_utf8 and spew_utf8 to read and write files using the correct encoding
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Path-Tiny

o PDF::Reuse:
- Reuse and mass produce PDF documents
- https://metacpan.org/dist/PDF-Reuse
- This module has an important See Also

o pdftotext:
-  Poppler is a PDF rendering library based on the xpdf-3.0 code base
- https://poppler.freedesktop.org/
- Appears to be installed as part of Debian

o Random::Simple:
- Simple, usable, real world random numbers
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Random-Simple

o Text::Table::Manifold:
- Render tables in manifold formats
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Text::Table::Manifold
- Its See Also lists about similar 40 modules

o Text::Table::Tiny:
- Generate simple text tables from 2D arrays
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Text::Table::Tiny

o Thread::Subs:
- Execute selected subs concurrently in worker threads
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Thread-Subs
- The POD is very sophisticated

o Time::Moment:
- Represents a date and time of day with an offset from UTC
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Time-Moment

o Type::Registry:
- A glorified hashref for looking up type constraints
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Type::Registry

o Type::Tiny:
- Tiny, yet Moo(se)-compatible, type constraint
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Type-Tiny
- Contains Types::Standard and many other modules

o Types::Common:
- The one stop shop
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Types::Common

o utf8::all:
- Turn on Unicode - all of it
- https://metacpan.org/dist/utf8-all

"""

- https://metacpan.org/dist/HATX

o List::MoreUtils:
- Provide the stuff missing in List::Util
- https://metacpan.org/pod/List::MoreUtils

o List::Util:
- This is a core module
- Note: List::XS is available
- use List::Util 'any' or, better, 'first' (but don't use first() for finding 0 or undef!)
- And then 1 of:
- if(any { $_ eq $thing } @values) ...
- if(any { $_ == $thing } @values) ...
- It's not limited to just string or number comparison of course; you can
put any arbitrary code in there. if(any { $_->is_close_to(123.45) } @values) ...
- Or
- If you don't like the XSUB call overhead of List::any, there's
another (non-core) CPAN module List::Keywords which implements many of
the same utilities as real keywords with real opcodes, so they run
faster.
- use List::Keywords 'any';
- if(any { $_ eq $thing } @values) ...
- Or
- if (grep { $_ eq $myval } @arr)

o List::UtilsBy:
- Higher-order list utility functions

- Also, List::UtilsBy contains zip_by and unzip_by

text:
"""
o See also:
- BarCodes
- Chart
- Chart::Clicker
- Chart::GGPlot
- Chart::Plotly
- Color::Library
- Convert::Color
- Imager::Plot
- VS::Chart
- ChartingAndPlotting
- [[Color]]
- [[Graphs]]
- PdfStuff
- https://echarts.apache.org/
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ggplot2
- https://github.com/aluntzer/gtknodes/
- https://plot.ly/javascript/reference/

o Alien::CFITSIO:
- Build and Install the CFITSIO library
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Alien::CFITSIO
- See also https://heasarc.gsfc.nasa.gov/docs/software/fitsio/fitsio.html

o Alien::GtkNodes:
- Find or install GtkNodes
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Alien-GtkNodes

o App::BlurFill:
- A simple command line tool to create a blurred background image
- https://metacpan.org/dist/App-BlurFill
- Command line access to a Dancer app
- curl -OJ -X POST http://localhost:5000/blur -F "image=@input.jpg"

o App::gimpgitbuild:
- Build GIMP from git
- https://metacpan.org/pod/App::gimpgitbuild

o App::ImageMagickUtils:
- https://metacpan.org/dist/App-ImageMagickUtils

o App::Image::Generator:
- Perl class for image-generator application
- https://metacpan.org/dist/App-Image-Generator

o App::imgsize:
- Show dimensions of image files
- https://metacpan.org/pod/App::imgsize

o Cairo:
- Perl interface to the cairo 2d vector graphics library
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Cairo

o Chart::ECharts:
- Apache ECharts wrapper for Perl
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Chart::ECharts

o File::LibMagic:
- Determine MIME types of data or files using libmagic
- https://metacpan.org/pod/File::LibMagic

o GD:
- Interface to Gd Graphics Library
- https://metacpan.org/pod/GD

o GD::Polyline:
- Polyline object and Polygon utilities (including splines) for use with GD
- https://metacpan.org/pod/GD::Polyline

o GD::Simple:
- Simplified interface to GD library
- https://metacpan.org/pod/GD::Simple
- Tutorial on usage at http://perlmaven.com/drawing-images-using-gd-simple

o GD::SVG:
- Seamlessly enable SVG output from scripts written using GD
- https://metacpan.org/pod/GD::SVG

o Gimp:
- Write GIMP extensions/plug-ins/load- and save-handlers in Perl
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Gimp
- Git repo for the module is at https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gimp-perl

o Graphics::Framebuffer:
- A Simple Framebuffer Graphics Library
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Graphics-Framebuffer

o Graphics::Penplotter::GcodeXY:
- Produce gcode files for pen plotters from Perl
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Graphics-Penplotter-GcodeXY

o HTML::D3:
- A simple Perl module for generating bar charts using D3.js
- https://metacpan.org/dist/HTML-D3

o Image::APNG:
- Generate Animated PNG (APNG) files from individual PNG images
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Image-APNG

o Image::Base:
- And it's submodules

o Image::Base::GD:
- Draw images with GD

o Image::Bitmap2Paths:
- Perl extension to convert line-drawing (and font's) bitmaps to paths (of vector formats)
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Image-Bitmap2Paths

o Image::Dot:
- Create 1x1 pixel image files (pure-perl)
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Image::Dot

o Image::ExifTool:
- The command line tool exiftool has many, many options and supports a vast array of types
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Image-ExifTool
- https://exiftool.org/:
- http://exiftool.sourceforge.net/

o Image::ExifTool::TagNames:
- ExifTool tag name documentation
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Image-ExifTool/

o Image::Info:
- Extract meta information from image files
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Image-Info

o Image::JPEG::Size:
- Find the size of JPEG images
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Image-JPEG-Size

o ImageMagick:
- sudo apt-get install imagemagick
- https://imagemagick.org/Usage/
- Site has a list of exploits and many examples

o Image::Magick::Safer:
- Wrap Image::Magick Read method to check magic bytes
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Image-Magick-Safer

o Image::Magick::Thumbnail::PDF:
- Make thumbnail of a page in a pdf document

o Image::MetaData::JPEG:
- Perl extension for showing/modifying JPEG (meta)data
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Image::MetaData::JPEG
- But see Image::ExifTool

o Image::PNG::Libpng:
- Perl interface to the C library libpng
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Image::PNG::Libpng

o Image::PNG::QRCode:
- ABANDONED - Make PNG images containing QR codes from your text
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Image-PNG-QRCode

o Image::Synchronize:
- Synchronize filesystem modification timestamps of images, movies, and related files
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Image-Synchronize

o Image::ThumbHash:
- A very compact representation of an image placeholder
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Image-ThumbHash

o Imager:
- Perl extension for Generating 24 bit Images
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Imager
- To get my demo test.imager.tiles.pl of Imager running, I had to do:
- sudo aptitude install libpng-dev
- sudo aptitude install libfreetype6-dev
- sudo aptitude install libfont-freetype-perl
- Probably the 1st and 3rd only are required

o Imager::File::QOI:
- Read and write QOI image files
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Imager-File-QOI

o Imager::File::TIFF:
- Read and write TIFF files
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Imager-File-TIFF

o Imager::Font::FT2:
- Font support using FreeType 2
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Imager::Font::FT2

o Matplotlib::Simple:
- Simple plotting
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Matplotlib-Simple
- Note: POD is useless

o PDL::Drawing::Prima:
- PDL-aware drawing functions for Prima widgets
- https://metacpan.org/dist/PDL-Drawing-Prima

o PDL::Graphics::PLplot:
- https://metacpan.org/pod/PDL::Graphics::PLplot
- Object-oriented interface from perl/PDL to the PLPLOT plotting library
o PGPLOT:
- Allow subroutines in the PGPLOT graphics library to be called from Perl
- https://metacpan.org/dist/PGPLOT

o Prima:
- A Perl graphic toolkit
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Prima

o Prima::Cairo:
- Prima extension for Cairo drawing
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Prima::Cairo

o Resizing images:
- Calculate dimensions of image/video resized by ImageMagick-like geometry specification
- Math::Image::CalcResized

o SVG:
- Perl extension for generating Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG) documents
- https://metacpan.org/pod/SVG

o SVG::Barcode:
- Base class for SVG 1D and 2D codes
- https://metacpan.org/pod/SVG::Barcode

o SVG::Barcode::UPCA:
- Generator for SVG based UPCA barcodes
- https://metacpan.org/dist/SVG-Barcode-UPCA

o SVG::Timeline:
- Create SVG timeline charts
- https://metacpan.org/dist/SVG-Timeline

o SVG::TrafficLight:
- Perl extension to produce SVG diagrams of traffic lights
- https://metacpan.org/dist/SVG-TrafficLight

o WebGPU::Direct:
- Direct access to the WebGPU native APIs
- https://metacpan.org/pod/WebGPU::Direct

text:
""" o See also: - AnyEvent::Run - AnyEvent::Util - Argv - CachingStuff - For Net::Clacks - Capture::Tiny - Child - EventStuff - Forks::Super - [[HTTPHandling]] - IPC::Capture - IPC::Command::Multiplex - IPC::Exe - IPC::Open3 - IPC::Open3::Simple - IPC::RunSession::Simple - IPC::ShellCmd - IPC::System::Simple - ModulePlugins - ParallelProcessing - PoeStuff - [[POSIX]] - Proc::ProcessTable::Colorizer - Proc::Spawn - Spawn::Safe - System::Command 
o Alternatives copies from the POD of Sys::Cmd:
AnyEvent::Run, AnyEvent::Util, Argv, Capture::Tiny, Child, Forks::Super, IO::Pipe, IPC::Capture, IPC::Cmd, IPC::Command::Multiplex, IPC::Exe, IPC::Open3, IPC::Open3::Simple, IPC::Run, IPC::Run3, IPC::RunSession::Simple, IPC::ShellCmd, IPC::System::Simple, POE::Pipe::TwoWay, Proc::Background, Proc::Fork, Proc::FastSpawn, Spawn::Safe, System::Command
o Acme::Ghost: - Yet another view to daemon processes - https://metacpan.org/dist/Acme-Ghost o App::ProcUtils: - Command line utilities related to processes - https://metacpan.org/dist/App-ProcUtils o Command::Run: - Execute external command or code reference - https://metacpan.org/pod/Command::Run o Command::Runner: - Run external commands and Perl code refs - https://metacpan.org/dist/Command-Runner o CTK: - CTK ToolKit library (CTKlib) - https://metacpan.org/pod/CTK o CTK::Daemon: - Abstract class to implement Daemons - https://metacpan.org/pod/CTK::Daemon o Daemon::Control: - Create init scripts in Perl - https://metacpan.org/pod/Daemon::Control o Daemon::Daemonize: - An easy-to-use daemon(izing) toolkit - https://metacpan.org/pod/Daemon::Daemonize o Daemon::Device: - Forking daemon device construct - https://metacpan.org/pod/Daemon::Device o Daemon::Generic: - Framework to provide start/stop/reload for a daemon - https://metacpan.org/pod/Daemon::Generic o HTTP::Daemon: - A simple http server class - https://metacpan.org/pod/HTTP::Daemon o Forks::Super: - Extensions and convenience methods to manage background processes - https://metacpan.org/pod/Forks::Super - Provides new definitions for the Perl functions fork, wait, and waitpid with richer functionality o IO::Pipely: - Portably create pipe() or pipe-like handles, one way or another - https://metacpan.org/pod/IO::Pipely o IPC::Cmd: - Finding and running system commands made easy - https://metacpan.org/pod/IPC::Cmd - system() and background procs w/ piping, redirs, ptys (Unix, Win32) - Can use IPC::Run o IPC::LockTicket: - Use Storable library to IPC token to prevent parallel access to any resources. Including your custom data to transfer asynchronously - https://metacpan.org/dist/IPC-LockTicket o IPC::MicroSocket: - Minimal request/response or pub/sub mechanism - https://metacpan.org/dist/IPC-MicroSocket o IPC::Run: - system() and background procs w/ piping, redirs, ptys (Unix, Win32) - https://metacpan.org/pod/IPC::Run - IPC::Run is a much more complete solution for running child processes (than the next) o IPC::Run3: - Run a subprocess with input/output redirection - https://metacpan.org/pod/IPC::Run3 - POD contains important comparison with various similar modules o IPC::Shareable: - Use shared memory backed variables across processes - https://metacpan.org/pod/IPC::Shareable o MooseX::Daemonize: - Role for daemonizing your Moose based application - https://metacpan.org/pod/MooseX::Daemonize o Net::Daemon: - Perl extension for portable daemons - https://metacpan.org/pod/Net::Daemon o Proc::Application::Daemon: - Daemon class based on Proc::Application - https://metacpan.org/dist/Proc-Application o Proc::Background: - Much simpler than the above - https://metacpan.org/dist/Proc-Background - Supports Linux and MS Windows - Refers to the previous module - Refers to the Win32 module below o Proc::Daemon: - Run Perl program(s) as a daemon process - https://metacpan.org/dist/Proc-Daemon o Proc::Fork: - Simple, intuitive interface to the fork() system call - https://metacpan.org/pod/Proc::Fork o Proc::Forking: - Provides a set of tool to fork and daemonize - https://metacpan.org/pod/Proc::Forking o Proc::Forkmap: - Map with forking - https://metacpan.org/dist/Proc-Forkmap o Proc::Govern: - Run child process and govern its various aspects - https://metacpan.org/dist/Proc-Govern o Proc::ProcessTable: - Perl extension to access the unix process table - https://metacpan.org/pod/Proc::ProcessTable o Proc::Simple: - Launch and control background processes - https://metacpan.org/pod/Proc::Simple o Sys::Cmd: - Run a system command or spawn a system processes - https://metacpan.org/pod/Sys::Cmd o Win32::Console::DotNet: - Win32::Console .NET interface - https://metacpan.org/dist/Win32-Console-DotNet o Win32::ShellQuote: - Everyone quotes command line arguments the wrong way - https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/archive/blogs/twistylittlepassagesallalike/everyone-quotes-command-line-arguments-the-wrong-way o Workflow::Inotify: - Script to daemonize a Linux::Inotify2 handler - https://metacpan.org/pod/Workflow::Inotify o Zleep: - Fork a new process, sleep for the number of ms and then execute the codeblock - https://metacpan.org/pod/Zleep

""" o See also: - DataTraversal - For Term::TablePrint - DataTypes - For Rope - ModuleBuilding - https://turso.tech/ - For Turso DB 
Output from Gemini:
- libtickit
- The Terminal Interface Construction Kit
- A high-level C library used for building interactive, full-screen terminal programs (TUIs)
- It is designed to be a more modern and flexible alternative to the classic ncurses library

Sample code from Dave Cross:
#!/usr/bin/env bash
BINDIR=`dirname $0`
BINDIR="$BINDIR/../bin"
TIMELINE="$BINDIR/timeline"
$TIMELINE --years_per_grid=10 < $BINDIR/../examples/henry-viii.dat > henry-viii.svg

Path to turso:
/home/ron/perl5/lib/perl5/x86_64-linux/auto/share/dist/Alien-Turso-CLI/bin/turso
o Aion::Run: - Role for console commands - https://metacpan.org/dist/Aion-Run o Alien::libtickit: - Alien wrapping for libtickit - https://metacpan.org/dist/Alien-libtickit - This module behaves like ExtUtils::PkgConfig o Alien::Turso::CLI: - Install and find Turso CLI - https://metacpan.org/pod/Alien::Turso::CLI o App::ansicolumn: - ANSI sequence aware column command - https://metacpan.org/dist/App-ansicolumn o App::ansifold: - Fold command handling ANSI terminal sequences - But see App::PMUtils o App::lms: - A utility to locate and display command or library files - https://metacpan.org/dist/App-lms - But see App::PMUtils o App::nup: - N-up output wrapper for optex -Mup - https://metacpan.org/dist/App-nup o App::oo_modulino_zsh_completion_helper: - Provides zsh completion for OO-Modulinos - https://metacpan.org/dist/App-oo_modulino_zsh_completion_helper o App::optex: - Let the diamond operator read from DATA if there's no ARGV - https://metacpan.org/dist/ARGV-OrDATA o CLI::Cmdline: - Minimal command-line parser with short/long options and aliases in pure Perl - https://metacpan.org/dist/CLI-Cmdline o CLI::Framework: - Build standardized, flexible, testable command-line applications - https://metacpan.org/pod/CLI::Framework o CLI::Helpers: - Subroutines for making simple command line scripts - https://metacpan.org/dist/CLI-Helpers o CLI::Simple: - A minimalist object oriented base class for CLI applications - https://metacpan.org/dist/CLI-Simple o cpanm-shcompgen: - Install modules from CPAN (and activate shell completion) - https://metacpan.org/pod/cpanm-shcompgen - """

- http://standards.freedesktop.org/desktop-entry-spec/desktop-entry-spec-latest.html - For .Desktop files

o Advanced::Config:
- Perl module reads configuation files from various sources
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Advanced::Config
- Advanced::Config is an enhanced implementation of a config file manager that allows you to manage almost any config file as a true object with a common interface

o App::Cme:
- Configuration data checker or editor based on Config::Model
- https://metacpan.org/dist/App-Cme
- Contains the cms command

- Manage application specific environments
- https://metacpan.org/dist/App-Env

o AppConfig:
- Perl5 module for reading configuration files and parsing command line arguments
- https://metacpan.org/pod/AppConfig

o Clearcase:
- Object oriented interface to Clearcase
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Clearcase
- IBM DevOps Code ClearCase (also known as IBM Rational ClearCase) supports software configuration management (SCM)

o Configuration Files:
- Hint: Start with Config::IOD::Reader below
- App::Options - Combine command line options, environment vars, and option file values (for program configuration). Also discusses a range of other config-type modules
- Config::ROFL - Yet another config module. Uses Config::ZOMG
- Config::ZOMG - Yet another layer over Config::Any
- Config::Any - Load configuration from different file formats, transparently
- Config::Dot
- ConfigReader::Simple - https://metacpan.org/pod/ConfigReader::Simple
- Config::Structured - Provides generalized and structured configuration value access
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Config-Structured
- Config::Simple::Conf
- Config::Parser
- Config::INI::Tiny
- Config::INI::RefVars - INI file reader, allows the referencing of INI and environment variables within the INI file
- Config::Param - All you want to do with parameters for your program (or someone else's)
  Also discusses a range of other config-type modules
- Config::Structured - Provides generalized and structured configuration value access
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Config::Structured
- Parse::PlainConfig - Provides hierarchical config file structures
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Parse::PlainConfig

o Config::Abstraction:
- Configuration Abstraction Layer
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Config::Abstraction

o Config::General:
- Generic Config Module
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Config-General
- Has many features

o Config::IniFiles:
- A module for reading .ini-style configuration files
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Config::IniFiles

o Config::INI::Reader:
- A subclassable .ini-file parser
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Config::INI::Reader

o Config::INI::Reader::Multiline:
- Parser for .ini files with line continuations
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Config-INI-Reader-Multiline

o Config::IOD:
- Read and write IOD/INI configuration files
- This module is a round-trip parser for IOD configuration format
- If you only need to read IOD configuration files, you might want to use Config::IOD::Reader instead
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Config::IOD
- See IOD below

o Config::IOD::Reader:
- Read IOD/INI configuration files
- It is a minimalist alternative to the more fully-featured Config::IOD
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Config::IOD::Reader
- See IOD below

o Config::Model:
- A framework to validate, migrate and edit configuration files
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Config-Model
- I hope you never need code this complex
- See also Config::Model::Tester

o Config::Model::Itself:
- Model (or schema) editor for Config::Model
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Config-Model-Itself

o Config::Model::OpenSsh:
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Config-Model-OpenSsh
- A graphical config editor for /etc/ssh/sshd_config, /etc/ssh/ssh_config and ~/.ssh/config

o Config::Model::Systemd:
- Editor and validator for systemd configuration files
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Config-Model-Systemd

o Config::Model::TkUI:
- Tk GUI to edit config data through Config::Model
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Config-Model-TkUI

o Config::MorePerl:
- Convenient and flexible config loader in perl format
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Config-MorePerl

o Config::Resolver:
- Recursively resolve placeholders in a data structure
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Config-Resolver

o Config::Simple:
- Simple configuration file class
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Config::Simple

o Config::Tiny:
- Read/Write .ini style files with as little code as possible
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Config::Tiny

o Config::Tiny::Ordered:
- Read/Write ordered .ini style files with as little code as possible
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Config::Tiny::Ordered

o Config::Writer:
- A module to write configuration files in an easy and safe way
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Config-Writer

o Env::Assert:
- Ensure that the environment variables match what you need, or abort
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Env-Assert

o Env::AsYaml:
- Is intended to be a tool for examination of the environment
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Env-AsYaml

o Env::Dot:
- Read environment variables from a .env file
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Env::Dot

o ENV::Util:
- https://metacpan.org/pod/ENV::Util
- Parse prefixed environment variables and dotenv (.env) files into Perl

o File::DesktopEntry:
- Object to handle .desktop files
- https://metacpan.org/dist/File-DesktopEntry

o IOD:
- IOD (INI On Drugs) file format specification
- https://metacpan.org/pod/IOD
- See Config::IOD and Config::IOD::Reader above

o Perinci::CmdLine::Config:
- Utility routines related to config files
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Perinci::CmdLine::Config

o TOML::Tiny:
- TOML aims to be a minimal configuration file format that's easy to read due to obvious semantics. TOML is designed to map unambiguously to a hash table
- https://github.com/toml-lang/toml
- See also the next 2 modules
- https://metacpan.org/pod/TOML
- https://metacpan.org/pod/TOML::Parser
- https://github.com/toml-lang/toml/wiki

text:
""" o See also: - [[CPAN]] o CPAN::Audit: - Audit CPAN distributions for known vulnerabilities - https://metacpan.org/dist/CPAN-Audit - This module contains cpan-audit, which uses a cpanfile or a cpanfile.snapshot file o Docs: - The docs here were copied from Google's Gemini, when I asked it how to generate a cpanfile 
**1. Manual Creation**

* **Create a file named `cpanfile`:** This file will reside in the root directory of your project.
* **Add dependencies:**
    * Each line in the `cpanfile` represents a dependency.
    * Use the following syntax: `require 'ModuleName';`
    * Example:
      ```perl
        require 'JSON';
        require 'Template';
        require 'DateTime';
        require 'DBIx::Class';
        `

**2. Using `Mojolicious::Command::Author::generate::cpanfile`**

* **Install the Mojolicious framework (if not already installed):**
    ```bash
    cpanm Mojolicious
    ```
* **Generate the `cpanfile`:**
    ```bash
    mojo generate cpanfile
    ```
    This command analyzes your Perl source code files (usually located in the `lib` directory) to identify used modules and generates the `cpanfile` accordingly.

**3. Using Carton**

* **Install Carton:**
    ```bash
    cpanm Carton
    ```
* **Create a `cpanfile`:**
    ```bash
    carton init
    ```
    This creates a basic `cpanfile` with some default settings. You can then manually add your project's specific dependencies.

**Key Considerations**

* **Version Constraints:** You can specify version constraints for your dependencies to ensure compatibility and stability. For example:
    ```perl
    require 'Module::Name' => '>= 1.2.3';
    ```
* **Local Modules:** If you have local modules that are not on CPAN, you can add them to your `cpanfile` using special directives.
* **Testing:** After generating your `cpanfile`, always test your application to ensure all dependencies are installed correctly and your application functions as expected.

**Example `cpanfile`**

```perl
require 'JSON';
require 'Template' => '>= 2.18';
require 'DateTime';
require 'DBIx::Class';
require 'MyLocalModule'; # A hypothetical local module
```

By using a `cpanfile`, you can easily manage and install the necessary dependencies for your Perl projects, making your development process more efficient and reproducible.
title: CpanFile

text:
""" o See also: - [[Acronyms]] - For GDB & GQL re Neo4j - AlgorithmicStuff - CommandLineStuff - For Alien::Turso::CLI - ConfigFiles - FileHandling - HashHandling - For Pivot::ArrayOfHashes - ModuleBuilding - UsernamePassword - https://blogs.perl.org/users/usna78/2024/05/mariadb-10-and-sqltranslatorproducer.html - https://duckdb.org/ - For DuckDB's feature-rich SQL dialect - https://man.he.net/man1/dig - For dig, similar to App::dnsq - https://metacpan.org/pod/ORLite - For an important discussion of SQLite - https://redis.io/ - https://theweeklychallenge.org/blog/dbix-class-async-evolution/ - For async techniques - https://turso.tech/ - For Turso DB 
Note: GraphViz2::DBI ships with db.schema.pl, which creates an SVG image of a schema:
- To run it you need to set three environment variables as below
- dbi.schema.pl takes an option parameter of image type, which defaults to svg
- Edit the code if you wish to change the output dir's name
- The last line, the copy, is for my setup. $DR points to a RAM disk. Debian automatically creates a RAM disk, so I configure the free web server Engine X, aka nginx, to use it. See my other TiddlyWiki, Debian.Wiki.html, for details about nginx
- And yes, you can use empty strings for the username and password
- Lastly, $ is just the command line prompt
$ DBI_DSN=dbi:SQLite:dbname=data/levies.sqlite
$ DBI_USER=local
$ DBI_PASS=local
$ export DBI_DSN DBI_USER DBI_PASS
$ mkdir html
$ dbi.schema.pl (my version)
$ cp html/dbi.schema.svg $DR/levy.schema.svg

File::LocalizeNewlines sample code:

- 1 of 2: dos2unix.pl:

#!/usr/bin/env perl

use 5.018;
use strict;
use warnings;

use File::LocalizeNewlines;

# --------------------

my($file_name) = shift || die "Usage: $0 file_name\n";
my($localizer) = File::LocalizeNewlines -> new(verbose => 1);

say $localizer -> localized($file_name) ? 'Yes' : 'No';

- 2 of 2: unix2dos.pl:

#!/usr/bin/env perl

use 5.018;
use strict;
use warnings;

use File::LocalizeNewlines;

# ---------------------

my($file_name) = shift || die "Usage: $0 file_name\n";
my($localizer) = File::LocalizeNewlines -> new(newline => "\015\012", verbose => 1);

say $localizer -> localized($file_name) ? 'Yes' : 'No';

text:
""" o See also: - ConstantStuff - DataTypes - DataTraversal - Hash::Util ships with Perl - [[HTTPHandling]] 
Code to test something hashy:
perl -MHash::Util=lock_keys -e '%hash = map {; $_ => $_ } (0 .. 1_000); lock_keys(%hash); for (1 .. 1_000_000) { my $x = $hash{ int(rand() * 1_000) } }'
Time take on my Lenovo Tiny desktop: real 0m0.143s
o CGI::Expand: - Convert flat hash to nested data using TT2's dot convention - https://metacpan.org/pod/CGI::Expand - Module's See Also is useful o Hash::Case: - Base class for hashes with key-casing requirements - https://metacpan.org/dist/Hash-Case o Hash::Flatten: - Flatten/unflatten complex data hashes - https://metacpan.org/pod/Hash::Flatten o Hash::Match: - Match contents of a hash against rules - https://metacpan.org/dist/Hash-Match o Hash::Merge::Simple: - Recursively merge two or more hashes, simply - https://metacpan.org/pod/Hash::Merge::Simple o Hash::MultiValue: - Store multiple values per key - https://metacpan.org/pod/Hash::MultiValue o Hash::Util: - A selection of general-utility hash subroutines - https://metacpan.org/pod/Hash::Util o Hash::Exists::Tiny: - Some hash helper functions related to perl's "exists" function. - https://metacpan.org/dist/Hash-Util-Exists-Tiny o Hash::FieldHash: - Support for Inside-Out Classes - https://metacpan.org/pod/Hash::FieldHash o Hash::FieldHash::Compat: - Use Hash::FieldHash or ties, depending on availability - https://metacpan.org/pod/Hash::FieldHash::Compat o Hash::Merge: - Utility functions for merging hashes - https://metacpan.org/dist/Hash-Util-Merge o Hash::Pick: - The non-destructive utilities for picking hash - https://metacpan.org/dist/Hash-Util-Pick o Hash::Set: - Set operations on hash keys - https://metacpan.org/dist/Hash-Util-Set o Hash::Set::XS: - XS implementation of Hash::Set - https://metacpan.org/dist/Hash-Util-Set-XS o Hash::Wrap: - Create on-the-fly objects from hashes - https://metacpan.org/pod/Hash::Wrap - The pod's SEE-ALSO has a great list of alternatives o HTTP::Rollup: - Translate an HTTP query string to a hierarchical structure - https://metacpan.org/pod/HTTP::Rollup o Pivot::ArrayOfHashes: - Pivot arrays of hashes, such as those returned by DBI - https://metacpan.org/pod/Pivot::ArrayOfHashes o Tie::Array::DBD: - Tie a plain array to a database table - https://metacpan.org/dist/Tie-Hash-DBD - Contains Tie::Hash::DBD o Tie::DBI: - Tie hashes to DBI relational databases - https://metacpan.org/dist/Tie-DBI o Tie::Hash: - Base class definitions for tied hashes - https://metacpan.org/pod/Tie::Hash - Contains Tie::StdHash, Tie::ExtraHash - Ships with Perl o Tie::Hash::Create: - Extend Tie::ExtraHash, enables the tie-object to reflect the tied array - https://metacpan.org/pod/Tie::Hash::Create o Tie::Hash::KeysMask: - Control key aliasing by mask function, e.g. omit case of character distinction - https://metacpan.org/dist/Tie-Hash-KeysMask o Tie::Hash::MultiValue: - Store multiple values per key - https://metacpan.org/pod/Tie::Hash::MultiValue o Tie::Hash::MultiValueOpts: - """ o See also: - JsonStuff o JE: - Pure-Perl ECMAScript (JavaScript) Engine - https://metacpan.org/dist/JE o JavaScript::Duktape: - Perl interface to Duktape embeddable javascript engine - https://metacpan.org/pod/JavaScript::Duktape - See also https://duktape.org/api.html and https://duktape.org/guide o JavaScript::Packer: - Perl version of Dean Edwards' Packer.js - https://metacpan.org/dist/JavaScript-Packer o JavaScript::QuickJS: - Run JavaScript via QuickJS in Perl - https://metacpan.org/dist/JavaScript-QuickJS o JavaScript::V8::XS: - Perl XS binding for the V8 Javascript embeddable engine - https://metacpan.org/pod/JavaScript::V8::XS o JQ::Lite: - A lightweight jq-like JSON query engine in Perl - https://metacpan.org/dist/JQ-Lite - Sample code: 
#/usr/bin/env perl

use JQ::Lite;

my $json = '{"users":[{"name":"Alice"},{"name":"Bob"}]}';
my $jq = JQ::Lite->new;
my @names = $jq->run_query($json, '.users[].name');
print join("\n", @names), "\n";

See the POD for JSON::SIMD, under Interoperability as above - It can be necessary. See ~/bin/test.cpanel.json.xs.type.pl - Code: 
#! /usr/bin/perl
use warnings;
use strict;

use Cpanel::JSON::XS qw{ encode_json };
use Cpanel::JSON::XS::Type;

my $struct = {Parts => [{PartNumber => "1",
                         ETag => "46f438ba2afd8d6dc03958b867a349b1"},
                        {ETag => "7b1e03e9ed7bb49d907e5a2d25b89159",
                         PartNumber => "2"},
                        {ETag => "30c23faad792c9b7c4b05356305cb6b0",
                         PartNumber => "3"},
                        {ETag => "979174e5353386a75d8e36d223d22ea2",
                         PartNumber => "4"},
                        {PartNumber => "5",
                         ETag => "ee93774d0a2ec9c27fae6a4fb3496804"},
                        {PartNumber => "6",
                         ETag => "9a2c5a1abe6869f370b07d76c270e569"}
             ]};
print encode_json($struct,
                  {Parts => json_type_arrayof({
                      PartNumber => JSON_TYPE_INT,
                      ETag       => JSON_TYPE_STRING})});

Output:
{"Parts":[{"ETag":"46f438ba2afd8d6dc03958b867a349b1","PartNumber":1},
{"ETag":"7b1e03e9ed7bb49d907e5a2d25b89159","PartNumber":2},

{"PartNumber":5,"ETag":"ee93774d0a2ec9c27fae6a4fb3496804"},
{"PartNumber":6,"ETag":"9a2c5a1abe6869f370b07d76c270e569"}]}

""" o See also: - Acronyms - EmailStuff - IpAddresses - MailingLists - PacketCapture - RegexpStuff - [[SSH]] - SystemMonitoring - WebServices - https://blog.urth.org/2021/03/29/security-issues-in-perl-ip-address-distros/ - https://github.com/netdisco/snmp-info/ - http://netdisco.org/ - https://suricata.io/ - For open source network analysis and threat detection - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MAC_Address o Acme::UPnP: - Cheap UPnP Port Mapping (IGD) - https://metacpan.org/pod/Acme::UPnP o App::Netdisco: - An open source web-based network management tool - https://metacpan.org/pod/App::Netdisco o App::NetdiscoX::Web::Plugin::Observium: - Port Traffic Links and Thumbnail Graphs from Observium - https://metacpan.org/pod/App::NetdiscoX::Web::Plugin::Observium o App::ReslirpTunnel: - A wrapper for the reslirp-tunnel application over SSH for remote connections - https://metacpan.org/dist/App-ReslirpTunnel o Check::NetworkSpans: - See if bidirectional traffic is being seen on spans - https://metacpan.org/dist/Check-NetworkSpans o Check::SuricataFlows: - Make sure Suricata is seeing data via reading the Suricata flows json - https://metacpan.org/dist/Check-SuricataFlows o Control::CLI: - Command Line Interface I/O over either Telnet or SSH (IPv4 & IPv6) or Serial port - https://metacpan.org/dist/Control-CLI o Control::CLI::Extreme: - Interact with CLI of Extreme Networking products over any of Telnet, SSH or Serial port - https://metacpan.org/dist/Control-CLI-Extreme o Device::MAC: - Handle hardware MAC Addresses (EUI-48 and EUI-64) - https://metacpan.org/pod/Device::MAC o Device::OUI: - Resolve an Organizationally Unique Identifier - https://metacpan.org/pod/Device::OUI o Device::WWN: - Encode/Decode Fiber Channel World Wide Names - https://metacpan.org/pod/Device::WWN o FTN::Addr: - Working with FTN addresses - https://metacpan.org/pod/FTN::Addr o grepcidr: - Filter IPv4 and IPv6 addresses matching CIDR patterns - https://www.pc-tools.net/unix/grepcidr/ - See Acronyms o libnet: - This is a collection of perl5 modules which all related to network programming. The majority of the modules available provide the client side of popular server-client protocols - https://metacpan.org/dist/libnet - Includes: - libnetFAQ - https://metacpan.org/dist/libnet/view/lib/Net/libnetFAQ.pod 
Net::Cmd - Network Command class (as used by FTP, SMTP etc)
Net::Config - Local configuration data for libnet
Net::Domain - Attempt to evaluate the current host's internet name and domain
Net::FTP  - FTP Client class
Net::FTP::dataconn - FTP Client data connection class
Net::NNTP - NNTP Client class
Net::Netrc - OO interface to users netrc file
Net::POP3 - Post Office Protocol 3 Client class (RFC1939)
Net::SMTP - Simple Mail Transfer Protocol Client
Net::Time - time and daytime network client interface
- See also Net::LMTP2 - A client class for the LMTP protocol which claims to fix Net::SMTP o ipgrep: - Grep files by CIDR o Mnet: - Modules are for perl programmers who want to create testable network automation and/or reporting scripts as simply as possible o Net::CIDR::Lite: - https://perladvent.org/2022/2022-12-17.html o Net::CIDR::Set: - Manipulate sets of IP addresses - https://metacpan.org/dist/Net-CIDR-Set o Net::IP: - Perl extension for manipulating IPv4/IPv6 addresses - https://metacpan.org/pod/Net::IP o Net::IP::XS: - IPv4/IPv6 address library - https://metacpan.org/dist/Net-IP-XS o Net::MAC: - Perl extension for representing and manipulating MAC addresses - https://metacpan.org/pod/Net::MAC o Net::MacMap: - A module used to determine the vendor of an interface based on the MAC addres - https://metacpan.org/pod/Net::MacMap - But see the next module o Net::MAC::Vendor: - Look up the vendor for a MAC - https://metacpan.org/dist/Net-MAC-Vendor o Net::Netmask: - Parse, manipulate and lookup IP network blocks - https://metacpan.org/dist/Net-Netmask o Net::Packet: - A framework to easily send and receive frames from layer 2 to layer 7 - https://metacpan.org/dist/Net-Packet o Net::Patricia: - Patricia Trie perl module for fast IP address lookups - https://metacpan.org/dist/Net-Patricia o Net::SIP: - Framework SIP (Voice Over IP, RFC3261) - https://metacpan.org/dist/Net-SIP o Net::UPnP: - Perl extension for UPnP - https://metacpan.org/dist/Net-UPnP o Net::UPnP::AV::MediaServer: - Perl extension for UPnP - https://metacpan.org/pod/Net::UPnP::AV::MediaServer o Net::UPnP::ControlPoint: - Perl extension for UPnP control point - https://metacpan.org/pod/Net::UPnP::ControlPoint o Net::Versa::Director: - Versa Director REST API client library - https://metacpan.org/pod/Net::Versa::Director o NetAddr::MAC: - MAC hardware address functions and object (EUI48 and EUI64) - https://metacpan.org/dist/NetAddr-MAC o NetBox::API: - Perl interface to NetBox API - https://metacpan.org/release/KORNIX/NetBox-API-0.1.0 - https://netboxlabs.com/docs/netbox/ o NetBox::Client: - Perl5 interface to NetBox API - https://metacpan.org/dist/NetBox-Client o NetPacket::LACP: - Assemble and disassemble IEEE 802.1D Spanning Tree protocol packets - https://metacpan.org/dist/NetPacket-LACP o NetPacket::LLC: - Assemble and disassemble IEEE 802.3 LLC protocol packets - https://metacpan.org/dist/NetPacket-LLC o NetPacket::SpanningTree: - Assemble and disassemble IEEE 802.1D Spanning Tree protocol packets - https://metacpan.org/dist/NetPacket-SpanningTree o Ryu: - Asynchronous Stream Building Blocks - Has good SEE ALSO o SNMP::Info: - OO Interface to Network devices and MIBs through SNMP - https://metacpan.org/dist/SNMP-Info o socat: - Socat is a command line based utility that establishes two bidirectional byte streams and transfers data between them - https://github.polettix.it/ETOOBUSY/2022/03/22/socat-local-to-remote-port/ o Webservice::InternetDB::API: - Fast IP Lookups for Open Ports and Vulnerabilities using InternetDB API - https://metacpan.org/pod/Webservice::InternetDB::API - Uses https://internetdb.shodan.io/ - Refers to https://www.freepublicapis.com/

- $n ‚àà @nums          # like  any { $n == $_ } @nums
- Yes, this is a UTF-8 named operator. No I will not apologise

o Syntax::Operator::Equ:
- Equality operators that distinguish undef
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Syntax::Operator::Equ
- $str equ $str        # like eq but cares about undef
- $num === $num  # like == but cares about undef

o Syntax::Operator::Elem:
- elem and similar operators, and the `in` meta-operator allow you to easily ask the question "does this string appear in that set of strings?" or similar for numbers. Useful combined with match/case
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Syntax::Operator::Elem
- Samples:
- $x elem @strings   # is a stringy comparison
- $x ‚àà @numbers    # is a numbery comparison
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Syntax::Operator::In
- $x in:isa @classes

o Syntax::Operator::Is:
- Match operator using Data::Checks constraints
- https://metacpan.org/dist/Syntax-Operator-Is

o Syntax::Operator::Zip:
- Infix operator to compose two lists together
- https://metacpan.org/pod/Syntax::Operator::Zip
- @list Z @list       # like List::zip but faster
- @list M @list       # like List::mesh but faster

- https://metacpan.org/dist/XS-Parse-Keyword

https://qpdf.sourceforge.io/ - Here is the Git repository for qpdf: https://github.com/qpdf/qpdf - Documentation for qpdf is here: https://qpdf.readthedocs.io/en/stable/ - Debian-specific notes follow. I'm using bookworm - libqpdf29 is installed by default for some reason - qpdf and qpdfview and libqpdf-dev can be installed with apt-get - qpfdview is a very convenient multi-doc (tabbed) viewer - Sample code, given x.pdf is say in v 1.6 format s output by LibreOffice: - qpdf --force-version=1.4 x.pdf x-1.4.pdf o SVGPDF: - Create PDF XObject from SVG data - https://metacpan.org/pod/SVGPDF - This module processes SVG data and produces one or more PDF XObjects to be placed in a PDF document. This module is intended to be used with PDF::Builder, PDF::API2 and compatible PDF packages o WWW::Mechanize::Chrome::Webshot: - Cheap and cheerful html2pdf converter, take a screenshot of rendered HTML, complete with CSS and Javascript - https://metacpan.org/dist/WWW-Mechanize-Chrome-Webshot 
o Google Bard says:
Command-line options:

    DiffPDF: Lightweight and simple, free and open-source. Compares text and images, highlights differences, can exclude margins and generate reports. However, lacks advanced features like layout or visual side-by-side comparison.
    Wdiff: Text-based diff tool, often installed by default. Good for textual comparisons, but not suitable for visual layout differences.

Graphical diff tools:

    Kompare: Powerful diff and merge tool for various file types, including PDFs. Supports side-by-side comparison, highlights differences, visual and textual comparisons. Has a steeper learning curve compared to simpler tools.
    Meld: Another popular diff and merge tool with side-by-side comparison, advanced filtering options, and support for directory comparisons.
    Diffuse: Lightweight GUI diff tool specifically for PDFs. Focuses on visual comparison with side-by-side view and highlighting. Lacks advanced features of some other tools.

Commercial options:

    Beyond Compare: Feature-rich diff and merge tool for various file types, including PDFs. Advanced comparison modes, visual and textual differences, filtering options, report generation, etc. Paid software.
    DiffMerge: Cross-platform diff tool with a GUI and powerful comparison engine for files and directories. Supports PDF comparison with side-by-side view, text alignment, and highlighting. Paid software.

Web-based options:

    Copyleaks: Online plagiarism checker that can compare PDFs and highlight text differences. Supports multiple languages. Free trial available, then paid subscription.

Here are some additional factors to consider when choosing a PDF comparison tool:

    Complexity of PDFs: For simple PDFs with just text, basic tools like DiffPDF might suffice. More complex PDFs with layouts and images might require something like Kompare or DiffMerge.
    Type of comparison: Do you need purely textual comparison, visual layout comparison, or both?
    Advanced features: Do you need options like filtering, reporting, or merging the PDFs?
    Budget: Some tools are free and open-source, while others are paid commercial options

text:
""" o Where can I learn about Object Oriented Programming (OOP)? - https://metacpan.org/dist/Marlin/view/lib/Marlin/Manual/Beginning.pod - https://metacpan.org/pod/HTML::Tree::AboutObjects - For the article: "User's View of Object-Oriented Modules" o What is Semantic Versioning? - https://semver.org/ - For Semantic Versioning o Where do I find info on iterators? - See DataTraversal o Why don't you include Catalyst, Dancer, Moose, etc? - My time is limited. - And I have my preferences aka biases: Moo instead of Moose. Mojolicious instead of all the alternatives o Why are AI agents so dangerous: - The fundamental problem is that AI must compress reality into model-legible forms. In this setting, adversaries can exploit the compression. They don‚Äôt have to attack the territory; they can attack the map. Models lack local contextual knowledge. They process symbols, not meaning. A human sees a suspicious URL; an AI sees valid syntax. And that semantic gap becomes a security gap - https://www.schneier.com/crypto-gram/archives/2025/1115.html#cg4 o What is prompt injection: - It is semantic mimicry: adversarial instructions that resemble legitimate prompts, which trigger self-compromise 
In security, we often assume that foreign/hostile code looks different from legitimate instructions, and we use signatures, patterns, and statistical anomaly detection to detect it. But getting inside someone‚Äôs AI OODA loop uses the system‚Äôs native language. The attack is indistinguishable from normal operation because it is normal operation. The vulnerability isn‚Äôt a defect‚Äîit‚Äôs the feature working correctly
- https://www.schneier.com/crypto-gram/archives/2025/1115.html#cg4 o Why is prompt injection dangerous: - LLMs process token sequences, but no mechanism exists to mark token privileges. The LLM can't tell the difference between legitimate input and corrupt input, so can be tricked into giving the latter priority. This might make it unsolvable in today‚Äôs LLMs - https://www.schneier.com/crypto-gram/archives/2025/1115.html#cg4 o What is the problem: - In training, we face poisoned datasets and backdoored models. In inference, we face adversarial inputs and prompt injection. During operation, we face a contaminated context and persistent compromise. We need semantic integrity: verifying not just data but interpretation, not just content but context, not just information but understanding. We can add checksums, signatures, and audit logs. But how do you checksum a thought? How do you sign semantics? How do you audit attention? - https://www.schneier.com/crypto-gram/archives/2025/1115.html#cg4
title: QandA

text:
""" o See also: - NetworkProgramming - https://perldoc.perl.org/ - PerlDoc 
 >    for (@numbers) {
 >       say "$_ is a single-digit number" if m/^\d$/;
 >    }
Variant:
say "$_ is a single-digit number"
   for grep m{\A \d \Z}aax, @numbers;

Also, never forget the aa-modifiers if you want to limit \d to [0-9].

perl -E 'say "\x{0660}\n" =~ /^\d$/'
1

And use \z if the newline is undesired.

- Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures

- https://www.redhat.com/en/topics/security/what-is-cve
- CPANSec has just been authorized as a CVE Numbering Authority (CNA) for Perl and modules on CPAN (2025-02-26)
- https://security.metacpan.org/2025/02/25/cpansec-is-cna-for-perl-and-cpan.html
- This allows us to issue and manage CVEs for that scope, and to help facilitate coordinated disclosure. If you need a CVE you can request one by emailing:
- cve-request@security.metacpan.org.
- If a third-party requests a CVE we will ensure that they have reached out to perl-security (or the CPAN author) first and facilitate a discussion if necessary

The CVE.org CNA record also provides the email address to request a CVE
number.

https://www.cve.org/PartnerInformation/ListofPartners/partner/CPANSec

Additional details are available in the CNA disclosure policy.

https://security.metacpan.org/docs/cna-disclosure-policy.html

Stig Palmquist (STIGTSP), Timothy Legge (TIMLEGGE) and Breno G. de Oliveira
(GARU) are administering the CNA.  If you are interested in helping or
learning more please contact us at cna@security.metacpan.org.

""" o See also: - CpanFile - DataTraversal - DatesAndTimes - DebuggingStuff - For Debug::* & Devel::* - ExceptionHandling - FileHandling - ModuleBuilding - NewOperators - PodHandling - For various POD spelling checkers - StringStuff - Test::InDomain within DataValidation - test.openssl.pl - Test regexps - WantArray - https://fast2-matrix.cpantesters.org/ - For test results for any module - https://magpie.cpantesters.org/ - https://perlmaven.com/devel-cover-for-markua-parser 
Users are encouraged to switch away from the Test::* suite to Test2::* (below).
See also T2
o A directory-per-test setup: - A script to set up a new directory+cpanm for each type of testing - https://github.com/MartijnLievaart/penv o A guide to testing: - Tips for testing Perl modules via GitHub - https://github.com/FGasper/perl-github-action-tips o App::PrereqGrapher: - Generate dependency graph using Perl::PrereqScanner - https://metacpan.org/pod/App::PrereqGrapher o App::Prove: - Implements the prove command - https://metacpan.org/pod/App::Prove - Part of Test::Harness (below) o App::Prove::Plugin::SetEnv: - A prove plugin to set environment variables - https://metacpan.org/pod/App::Prove::Plugin::SetEnv o App::ReportPrereqs: - Report prerequisite versions - https://metacpan.org/pod/App::ReportPrereqs o App::SimpleScan: - simple_scan's core code - https://metacpan.org/dist/App-SimpleScan - Contains simple_scan and simple_report and many examples - simple_scan reads test specifications from standard input and generates Perl code based on these specifications o App::Test::Generator: - Generate fuzz and corpus-driven test harnesses - https://metacpan.org/dist/App-Test-Generator o Archive::Merged: - Virtually merge two archives - https://metacpan.org/dist/Archive-Merged - Meaning you can interrogate one or more archives or directories o Assert::Refute: - Unified testing and assertion tool - https://metacpan.org/dist/Assert-Refute o assertions: - Select assertions in blocks of code - https://metacpan.org/pod/assertions o Carp::Assert: - Executable comments - https://metacpan.org/pod/Carp::Assert o Carp::Assert::More: - Convenience assertions for common situations - https://metacpan.org/pod/Carp::Assert::More o Chicken::Ipsum: - Generate random chicken noises - https://metacpan.org/dist/Chicken-Ipsum o circular::require: - Detect circularity in use/require statements - https://metacpan.org/pod/circular::require - See also Test::CircularDependencies o Config::Model::Tester: - Test framework for Config::Model - https://metacpan.org/dist/Config-Model-Tester o CPAN test results for a typical module: - https://matrix.perl-magpie.org/dist.php?dist=Tree-DAG_Node - https://fast2-matrix.cpantesters.org/?dist=Tree%3A%3ADAG_Node o CPAN::Test::Dummy::Perl5::ModuleBuildTiny: - Test distribution that depends on Module::Build::Tiny - https://metacpan.org/dist/CPAN-Test-Dummy-Perl5-ModuleBuildTiny o CPAN::Test::Dummy::Perl5::ExtUtilsMakeMaker: - Test distribution that depends on ExtUtils::MakeMaker - https://metacpan.org/dist/CPAN-Test-Dummy-Perl5-ExtUtilsMakeMaker o Cucumber::Messages: - Library of classes to encapsulate Cucumber messages - https://metacpan.org/dist/Cucumber-Messages o Cucumber::TagExpressions: - Tag expression parser - https://metacpan.org/dist/Cucumber-TagExpressions o Cucumber::Test::Release::Automation: - In lib/Cucumber/Test/Release/Automation.pm - https://metacpan.org/dist/Cucumber-Test-Release-Automation o Data::Compare: - Compare Perl data structures - https://metacpan.org/dist/Data-Compare o Data::Maker: - Simple, flexible and extensible generation of realistic data - Iincludes gender - https://metacpan.org/pod/Data::Maker o Data::Person: - Data object for person - Includes gender - https://metacpan.org/pod/Data::Person o Data::Random: - Perl module to generate random data - https://metacpan.org/pod/Data::Random o Data::RandomPerson: - Create random person data - Includes gender - https://metacpan.org/pod/Data::RandomPerson o Data::Random::Person: - Random person objects - https://metacpan.org/dist/Data-Random-Person - Could use Mock::Person::US instead of Mock::Person:CZ - Uses Data::Person - Includes gender o Data::Random::String::Matches: - Generate random strings matching a regex - https://metacpan.org/dist/Data-Random-String-Matches o Data::Random::Weighted: - Get weighted random data - https://metacpan.org/pod/Data::Random::Weighted - Limited to picking 1 item o Date::Range: - Work with a range of dates - https://metacpan.org/pod/Date::Range o Date::Simple: - A simple date object - https://metacpan.org/pod/Date::Simple o Data::SimplePassword: - Simple random password generator - https://metacpan.org/pod/Data::SimplePassword o DateTime::Event::Random: - DateTime extension for creating random datetimes - https://metacpan.org/pod/DateTime::Event::Random o DateTime::Event::Recurrence: - DateTime::Set extension for create basic recurrence sets - https://metacpan.org/pod/DateTime::Event::Recurrence o DBD::Mock::Session::GenerateFixtures: - This distribution generates fixtures for DBD-Mock-Session module - https://metacpan.org/pod/DBD::Mock::Session::GenerateFixtures o Environment::Is: - Detect environments like Docker or WSL - https://metacpan.org/dist/Environment-Is o Fennec: - (Deprecated} A testers toolbox, and best friend - https://metacpan.org/pod/Fennec o Gherkin: - A parser and compiler for the Gherkin language - https://metacpan.org/pod/Gherkin - See Test::BDD::Cucumber below o Getopt::Kingpin: - Command line options parser (like golang kingpin) - https://metacpan.org/dist/Getopt-Kingpin o HealthCheck: - A health check for your code - https://metacpan.org/dist/HealthCheck o HealthCheck::Parallel: - A HealthCheck that uses parallelization for running checks - https://metacpan.org/dist/HealthCheck-Parallel o JMAP::Tester: - A JMAP client made for testing JMAP servers - https://metacpan.org/pod/JMAP::Tester o JMAP::Tester::WebSocket: - A WebSocket JMAP client made for testing JMAP servers - https://metacpan.org/dist/JMAP-Tester-WebSocket o Keyword::DEVELOPMENT: - Have code blocks which don't exist unless you ask for them. - https://metacpan.org/pod/Keyword::DEVELOPMENT o Mock::Config: - Temporarily set Config or XSConfig values - https://metacpan.org/dist/Mock-Config o Mock::Data: - Extensible toolkit for generating mock data - https://metacpan.org/dist/Mock-Data - Has a dozen subclasses o Mock::Data::Regex: - Generator that uses a Regex as a template to generate strings - https://metacpan.org/pod/Mock::Data::Regex - Similar to String::Random::Regexp::regxstring in StringStuff o Mock::Person: - Generates random last, first and middle name of person - https://metacpan.org/pod/Mock::Person o Mock::Populate: - Mock data creation - https://metacpan.org/pod/Mock::Populate o Mockery: - Mock objects for testing purposes - https://metacpan.org/pod/Mockery o Module::Mask: - Pretend certain modules are not installed - https://metacpan.org/dist/Module-Mask o Perl::PrereqScanner: - A tool to scan your Perl code for its prerequisites - https://metacpan.org/dist/Perl-PrereqScanner - See also App::PrereqGrapher o PerlX::Assert: - Yet another assertion keyword - https://metacpan.org/pod/PerlX::Assert o Plack::Test::Agent: - OO interface for testing low-level Plack/PSGI apps - https://metacpan.org/dist/Plack-Test-Agent o Random::Day: - Class for random day generation - https://metacpan.org/pod/Random::Day o Random::Day::InTheFuture: - Class for random day generation in the future - https://metacpan.org/pod/Random::Day::InTheFuture o Random::Day::InThePast: - Class for random day generation in the past - https://metacpan.org/pod/Random::Day::InThePast o Random::Set: - Class for random set generation - https://metacpan.org/pod/Random::Set o Result::Simple: - A dead simple perl-ish Result like F#, Rust, Go, etc - https://metacpan.org/pod/Result::Simple - Result represents a function's return value as success or failure, enabling safer error handling and more effective control flow management o Return::Set: - Return a value optionally validated against a strict schema - https://metacpan.org/dist/Return-Set o Scientist: - Test new code against old. - https://metacpan.org/pod/Scientist o Sub::Assert: - Subroutine pre- and postconditions, etc - https://metacpan.org/pod/Sub::Assert o Subs::Trace: - Trace all calls in a package - https://metacpan.org/dist/Subs-Trace o Syntax::Keyword::Assert: - Assert keyword for Perl - https://metacpan.org/pod/Syntax::Keyword::Assert o TAP::DOM: - TAP as Document Object Model - https://metacpan.org/pod/TAP::DOM o TAP::Formatter::HTML: - TAP Test Harness output delegate for html output - https://metacpan.org/dist/TAP-Formatter-HTML o TAP::Harness: - Prove supports TAP::Harness plugins and has a plugin system of its own - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Harness - Usage: prove -Ilib [-j 9] -r t where t is the dir name - See "FORMATTERS" in prove, "SOURCE HANDLERS" in prove and App::Prove for more details o Tapper::Cmd: - Backend functions for CLI and Web - https://metacpan.org/dist/Tapper-Cmd - Search MetaCPAN for Tapper:: to find other components of this set o Task::Perl::Critic: - Install everything Perl::Critic - https://metacpan.org/pod/Task::Perl::Critic 
Start of the (old) Test::* suite
o Test::Against::Commit: - Test CPAN modules against Perl dev releases - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Against-Commit o Test::Against::Dev: - Test CPAN modules against Perl dev releases - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Against-Dev o Test::BDD::Cucumber: - Feature-complete Cucumber-style testing in Perl - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-BDD-Cucumber o Test::Builder: - Back-end for building test libraries - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::Builder o Test::CheckDeps: - Check for presence of dependencies - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::CheckDeps o Test::CheckGitStatus: - Check git status after every test - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-CheckGitStatus o Test::CircularDependencies: - Make sure non of the modules depend on themselves - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-CircularDependencies o Test::Class::Moose: - Serious testing for serious Perl - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Class-Moose o Test::CVE: - Test against known CVE's - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-CVE o Test::Data: - Provides utility functions to check properties and values of data and variables - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Data - See also Mock::Data above o Test::Database::Temp: - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Database-Temp - Create temporary test databases and run tests in all available ones - Database::Temp is also in DatabaseAndSQL o Test::Deep: - Extremely flexible deep comparison - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Deep - Has over 40 sub-modules o Test::Deep::Hashbag: - A Test::Deep hash comparator ignoring hash keys - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Deep-Hashbag o Test::Dependencies: - Ensure that the dependency listing is complete - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Dependencies o Test::DescribeMe: - Tell test runners what kind of test you are - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::DescribeMe o Test::Env: - Test the environment - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Env o Test::Exception: - Test exception-based code - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::Exception - See also Test::Fatal o Test::Expander: - Expansion of test functionalities that appear to be frequently used while testing - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Expander o Test::ExpectAndCheck: - Expect/check-style unit testing with object methods - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-ExpectAndCheck o Test::Fatal: - Incredibly simple helpers for testing code with exceptions - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Fatal - See also Test::Exception o Test::File: - Test file attributes - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-File o Test::File::Contents: - Test routines for examining the contents of files - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-File-Contents o Test::File::Cmp: - Test routine for file comparison independent of CRLF or LF line endings. - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-File-Cmp o Test::File::ShareDir: - Create a Fake ShareDir for your modules for testing - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::File::ShareDir o Test::Fixme: - Check code for FIXMEs - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Fixme o Test::Future::IO::Impl: - Acceptance tests for Future::IO implementations - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Future-IO-Impl o Test::Harness: - Run Perl standard test scripts with statistics - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Harness o Test::HTML::Content: - Perl extension for testing HTML output - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-HTML-Content o Test::HTTP::LocalServer: - Spawn a local HTTP server for testing - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-HTTP-LocalServer o Test::HTTPStatus: - Check an HTTP status - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-HTTPStatus o Test::Inline: - Embed your tests in your code, next to what is being tested - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::Inline o Test::Instruction: - A test framework - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Instruction o Test::Is: - Skip test in a declarative way, following the Lancaster Consensus - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::Is o Test::ISBN: - Check International Standard Book Numbers - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-ISBN o Test::JSON::Schema: - Test your data against a JSON Schema - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-JSON-Schema o Test::JSON::Schema::Acceptance: - Acceptance testing for JSON-Schema based validators - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::JSON::Schema::Acceptance o Test::Kit: - Build custom test packages with only the features you want - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::Kit - Similar modules: Import::Base, Toolset - Test::Kit largely differs from these in that it always makes your module behave like Test::More o Test::Manifest: - Interact with a t/test_manifest file - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Manifest o Test::MixedScripts: - Test text for mixed and potentially confusable Unicode scripts - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::MixedScripts - See also https://util.unicode.org/UnicodeJsps/confusables.jsp o Test::MockFile: - Allows tests to validate code that can interact with files without touching the file system - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-MockFile o Test::Mockingbird: - Advanced mocking library for Perl with support for dependency injection and spies - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Mockingbird o Test::MockModule: - Override subroutines in a module for unit testing - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-MockModule o Test::MockTime: - Replaces actual time with simulated time - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::MockTime o Test::MockTime::HiRes: - Replaces actual time with simulated high resolution time - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-MockTime-HiRes o Test::More: - See Test::Simple or Test::Simpler - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::More o Test::mysqld: - mysqld runner for tests - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::mysqld o Test::Needs: - Skip tests when modules not available - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::Needs o Test::NoWarnings: - Make sure you didn't emit any warnings while testing - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::NoWarnings o Test::Output: - Utilities to test STDOUT and STDERR messages - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Output o Test::Perl::Critic: - Use Perl::Critic in test programs - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::Perl::Critic o Test::Perl::Critic::Progressive: - Gradually enforce coding standards - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::Perl::Critic::Progressive o Test::PerlTidy: - Check that all your files are tidy - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-PerlTidy o Test::Pod::Spelling::CommonMistakes: - Checks POD for common spelling mistakes - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::Pod::Spelling::CommonMistakes o Test::PostgreSQL: - PostgreSQL runner for tests - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::PostgreSQL o Test::Prereq: - Check if Makefile.PL has the right prerequisites - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Prereq - Supersedes the next module o Test::Prereq::Meta: - Test distribution prerequisites against CPAN meta data file - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Prereq-Meta - But see Test::Prereq o Test::RedisServer: - Redis-server runner for tests - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-RedisServer o Test::Regexp::Pattern: - Test Regexp::Pattern patterns - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::Regexp::Pattern o Test::Returns: - Verify that a method's output agrees with its specification - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Returns o Test::Script: - Basic cross-platform tests for scripts - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Script o Test::Settings: - Ask or tell when certain types of tests should be run - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::Settings o Test::SFTP: - An object to help test SFTPs - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::SFTP o Test::Signature: - Automated SIGNATURE testing - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::Signature - See also Module::Signature in ModuleBuilding o Test::Simple: - Basic utilities for writing tests - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Simple - Has a huge array of components - Contains Test::More and Test2 - But see the next module o Test::Simpler: - Simpler than Test::Simple; more powerful than Test::More - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::Simpler o Test::Smoke: - The Perl core test smoke suite - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Smoke o Test::Spelling: - Check for spelling errors in POD files - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::Spelling o Test::SQLite: - SQLite setup/teardown for tests - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::SQLite o Test::TempDir::Tiny: - Temporary directories that stick around when tests fail - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-TempDir-Tiny - Strongly recommended over File::Temp which uses global "our" variables, which affects Capture::Tiny, since the latter also uses File::Temp. Don't do that o Test::Trap: - Trap exit codes, exceptions, output, etc - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::Trap o Test::Unit: - The PerlUnit testing framework - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Unit o Test::URI: - Check Uniform Resource Identifiers - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-URI o Test::utf8: - Handy utf8 tests - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-utf8 o Test::Warn: - Perl extension to test methods for warnings - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::Warn o Test::Warnings: - Test for warnings and the lack of them - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Warnings o Test::Which: - Skip tests if external programs are missing from PATH (with version checks) - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Which o Test::Without::Module: - Test fallback behaviour in absence of modules - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::Without::Module - See also Devel::Hide o Test::WWW::Mechanize: - Testing-specific WWW::Mechanize subclass - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-WWW-Mechanize - There are many similar modules on MetaCPAN - https://metacpan.org/search?size=20&q=Test%3A%3AWWW%3A%3AMechanize o Test::WWW::Simple: - Test Web applications using TAP - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::WWW::Simple o Test::XML: - Compare XML in perl tests - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::XML o Test::XML::Easy: - Test XML with XML::Easy - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::XML::Easy o XML::SemanticDiff: - Perl extension for comparing XML documents. - https://metacpan.org/pod/XML::SemanticDiff o Test::XML::Simple: - Easy testing for XML - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test::XML::Simple o Test::YAFT: - Yet another testing framework - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-YAFT 
Start of the Test2::* suite
o T2: - Define the T2 namespace that can always be used to access functionality from a Test2 bundle such as Test2::V1 - https://metacpan.org/dist/T2 o Test2::API: - Primary interface for writing Test2 based testing tools - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test2::API o Test2::Harness: - Contains yath, which replaces test and prove (see below for usage of prove) - https://metacpan.org/pod/yath. Install via App::Yath - https://perladvent.org/2023/2023-12-23.html o Test2::Plugin::SubtestFilter: - Filter subtests by name - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test2-Plugin-SubtestFilter o Test2::Plugin::UUID: - Use REAL UUIDs in Test2 - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test2-Plugin-UUID o Test2::Require::ProgramInPath: - Skip test unless a program exists in the PATH - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test2-Require-ProgramInPath o Test2::Tools - Documentation for Tools - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test2::Tools Test2::Tools - Documentation for Tools o Test2::Tools::ComboObject: - Combine checks and diagnostics into a single test as an object - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test2-Tools-ComboObject o Test2::Tools::DOM: - Tools to test HTML/XML-based DOM representations - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test2-Tools-DOM o Test2::Tools::LoadModule: - Test whether a module can be successfully loaded - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test2-Tools-LoadModule o Test2::Tools::PerlTidy: - Test2 check that all of your Perl files are tidy - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test2-Tools-PerlTidy o Test2::Tools::Pod: - Check that POD syntax is valid - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test2-Tools-Pod o Test2::Tools::Spec: - RSPEC implementation on top of Test2::Workflow - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test2::Tools::Spec o Test2::Tools::Subtest: - Tools for writing subtests - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test2::Tools::Subtest o Test2::Tools::TypeTiny: - Test2 tools for checking Type::Tiny types - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test2-Tools-TypeTiny o Test2::Transition: - Transition notes when upgrading to Test2 - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test-Simple/view/lib/Test2/Transition.pod - See also: https://metacpan.org/pod/Test2::Suite o Test2::DistFiles: - Gather files in a distribution - https://metacpan.org/dist/Test2-Util-DistFiles o Test2::V1: - V1 edition of the Test2 recommended bundle - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test2::V1 o Test2::Workflow: - A test workflow is a way of structuring tests using composable units - https://metacpan.org/pod/Test2::Workflow o Time::RTM: - Run-time metrics stats - https://metacpan.org/pod/Time::RTM o UNIVERSAL::dump: - Add dump and other methods to all classes and objects - https://metacpan.org/dist/UNIVERSAL-dump
title: TestingHelp

text:
""" o See also: - [[Color]] - DataTraversal - LaTeX - LinguaStuff - MarkdownHandling - PerlDocumentation - PodHandling - QrCodes - SpreadsheetStuff - StringStuff - TemplateStuff - [[UTF8]] - WikiStuff - [[XML]] - https://fontawesome.com/- For a huge list of icons - https://openrefine.org/ - OpenRefine is a powerful free, open source tool for working with messy data - https://pandoc.org/ - A universal document converter o Aion::Format: - Perl extension for formatting numbers, coloring output, etc - https://metacpan.org/dist/Aion-Format o Algorithm::Diff: - Compute differences between two files / lists - https://metacpan.org/pod/Algorithm::Diff o Algorithm::Diff::XS: - Algorithm::Diff with XS core loop - https://metacpan.org/pod/Algorithm::Diff::XS o Algorithm::LCS::XS: - Fast (XS) implementation of the Longest Common Subsequence (LCS) Algorithm - https://metacpan.org/dist/Algorithm-LCS-XS o Algorithm::MLCS: - Fast heuristic algorithm for finding Longest Common Subsequence of multiple sequences - https://metacpan.org/dist/Algorithm-MLCS o Antsy: - Streaming ANSI escape sequences - https://metacpan.org/pod/Antsy o App::AlgorithmDiffUtils: - CLI utilities based on Algorithm::Diff - https://metacpan.org/pod/App::AlgorithmDiffUtils o App::PPI::Dumper: - Use the PPI to dump the structure of a Perl file - https://metacpan.org/dist/App-PPI-Dumper o Data::Text: - Class to handle text in an OO way - https://metacpan.org/pod/Data::Text o Data::Text::Simple: - Data object for text in language - https://metacpan.org/pod/Data::Text::Simple o Dist::Surveyor: - Survey installed modules and determine the specific distribution versions they came from - https://metacpan.org/dist/Dist-Surveyor o File::MultipleDiff: - Compare multiple files - https://metacpan.org/pod/File::MultipleDiff o Hash::Diff: - Return difference between two hashes as a hash - https://metacpan.org/pod/Hash::Diff o HTML::Differences: - Reasonable sane HTML diffing - https://metacpan.org/pod/HTML::Differences o HTML::Quoted: - Extract structure of quoted HTML mail message - https://metacpan.org/pod/HTML::Quoted - Various MUAs use quite different approaches for quoting in emails - Purpose and returned structures are very similar to those in Text::Quoted - Uses HTML::Parser o Intellexer: - API client for Intellexer - https://metacpan.org/dist/Intellexer-API - Perl API client for the Intellexer, a webservice that, "enables developers to embed Intellexer semantics products using XML or JSON." 
- Features:
- Automatically extract topics from text
- Parse an input text stream and extract various linguistic information
- Automatically extracts sentiments (positivity/negativity), opinion objects (e.g., product features with associated sentiment phrases) and emotions (liking, anger, disgust, etc.) in unstructured text data
- Identifies elements in text and classifies them into predefined categories such as personal names, names of organizations, position/occupation, nationality, geographical location, date, age, duration and names of events
- Automatically generates a summary (short description) of a document with its main ideas
- With Related Facts automatically generates a summary (short description) from multiple documents with their main ideas
- Accurately compares documents of any format and determines the degree of similarity between them
- And more
o LCS: - Longest Common Subsequence - https://metacpan.org/dist/LCS - Contains LCS::Tiny o LCS::Similar: - Allow differences in the compared elements of Longest Common Subsequence (LCS) Algorithm - https://metacpan.org/dist/LCS-Similar o LCS::XS: - Fast (XS) implementation of the Longest Common Subsequence (LCS) Algorithm - https://metacpan.org/dist/LCS-XS o Pandoc: - Wrapper for the mighty Pandoc document converter - https://metacpan.org/pod/Pandoc o Parse::RecDescent: - Generate Recursive-Descent Parsers - https://metacpan.org/pod/Parse::RecDescent o Perl::MinimumVersion: - Find a minimum required version of perl for Perl code - https://metacpan.org/dist/Perl-MinimumVersion o PPI: - Parse, Analyze and Manipulate Perl (without perl) - https://metacpan.org/dist/PPI o PPIx::Regexp: - Represent a regular expression of some sort - https://metacpan.org/dist/PPIx-Regexp o PPIx::Utilities: - Extensions to PPI. - https://metacpan.org/pod/PPIx::Utilities o PPIx::Utils: - Utility functions for PPI - https://metacpan.org/pod/PPIx::Utils o PPR: - Pattern-based Perl Recognizer - https://metacpan.org/pod/PPI - The docs compare it with PPI o Regexp::Grammars: - Add grammatical parsing features to Perl 5.10 regexes - https://metacpan.org/pod/Regexp::Grammars o String::Diff: - Simple diff to String - https://metacpan.org/pod/String::Diff - Various ways of listing the difference between 2 strings o Tags: - Structure oriented SGML/XML/HTML/etc. elements manipulation - https://metacpan.org/pod/Tags o Template::Plugin::Autoformat: - Interface to Text::Autoformat module - https://metacpan.org/dist/Template-Plugin-Autoformat o Term::ANSIScreen: - Terminal control using ANSI escape sequences - https://metacpan.org/pod/Term::ANSIScreen o Text::ANSI::Fold: - Text folding library supporting ANSI terminal sequence and Asian wide characters with prohibition character handling - https://metacpan.org/dist/Text-ANSI-Fold o Text::ANSI::Printf: - Printf function to print string including ANSI sequence - https://metacpan.org/pod/Text::ANSI::Printf o Text::Autoformat: - Automatic text wrapping and reformatting - https://metacpan.org/pod/Text::Autoformat o Text::Balanced: - Extract delimited text sequences from strings - https://metacpan.org/dist/Text-Balanced o Text::Conceal: - Conceal and recover interface for text processing - text:
""" o See also: - WikiStuff - https://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/syntax - Syntax reference - https://feather.wiki/ - For Feather Wiki, a tiny version of a TiddlyWiki - https://tiddlywiki.com/ - The TiddlyWiki ecosystem 
o Escape character for '/' is '#&47;'. See also /''''/ and '////'. Click edit (pencil) to examine

o Care! TiddlyWikis contains executable code in order to provide all the features listed below:
- Your download or antivirus software might complain

o Overview:
- Each TiddlyWiki is restricted to a single web page
- Each page must use named paragraphs
- The purpose of these restrictions is to impose guidelines for the naming of things
- These guidelines help people with no expertise in data collation to index items carefully
- So, they help prevent growth-like-topsy, a major problem will old-style wikis
- Do yourself a favour and always include a para in every TiddlyWiki called MainMenu (or Index or TableOfContents), and put in it an alphabetical list of para names

o Inbuilt features of all TiddlyWikis:
- Search engine
- Editor (can be sent commands, and can generate HTML)
- The 3 double-quotes at the top of this para is one such command, but they are only visible when you click the pencil (edit) icon to enter edit mode for a para
- Encryption (good for passwords)
- History of paras edited per day
- Import capability (a way of sharing)
- Programmable in that you can list what paras are to be opened automatically when the file is loaded into the web client (browser). Hence the para called GettingStarted

o On-line help:
- See tiddlywiki.com for a free download and many add-ons from the eco-system
- The homepage is a TiddlyWiki, and you really should read the para GettingStarted
- It is quite different than my GettingStarted para
- In the eco-system there are various public hosting options giving other ways to share besides the import feature mentioned above
title: TiddlyWikis

o Unicode:

- Sample usage:
$ uniprops '‚òÉ'
U+2603 ‚Äπ‚òÉ‚Ä∫ \N{SNOWMAN}
...
$ uniprops 'U+2603'
U+2603 ‚Äπ‚òÉ‚Ä∫ \N{SNOWMAN}
...
$ uniprops 'SNOWMAN'
U+2603 ‚Äπ‚òÉ‚Ä∫ \N{SNOWMAN}
...
$ uni_id ‚òÉ
‚Äπ‚òÉ‚Ä∫ U+2603 SNOWMAN

$ uni_id √ß√†
‚Äπ√ß‚Ä∫ U+E7 LATIN SMALL LETTER C WITH CEDILLA
‚Äπ√†‚Ä∫ U+E0 LATIN SMALL LETTER A WITH GRAVE
- See also:
-Unicode::UCD
- Provides accsess at the information found in the Unicode Character Database.
The Unicode Standard is more than characters and properties.
- perluniprops
- unichars from Unicode-Tussle (e.g. unichars '\p{Hiragana}')
- See also charnames
- Sample usage:
use strict;
use warnings;
use feature      qw( say );
use experimental qw( regex_sets );

use utf8;                              # Source encoded using UTF-8.
use open ":std", ":encoding(UTF-8)";   # Terminal provides/expects UTF-8.

use charnames qw( :full );
use Encode    qw( decode_utf8 );

@ARGV == 1
   or die("usage\n");

my $s = decode_utf8($ARGV[0]);

for my $cp ( unpack "W*", $s ) {
   my $ch = chr($cp);
   if ( $ch =~ /(?[ \p{Print} - \p{Mark} ])/ ) {   # Not sure if good enough.
      printf "‚Äπ%s‚Ä∫ ", $ch;
   } else {
      print "--- ";
   }

   printf "U+%X ", $cp;

   say charnames::viacode($cp);
}

text:
""" o See also: - FileHandling - for FFI::* 
A comment on ZMQ from Paul Evans:
I found ZeroMQ to be a lot of effort to use from Perl, and most critically it does not appear to support both request/response and publish/subscribe message flows to share the same UNIX socket. To support that in ZeroMQ it would appear to be necessary to create two separate endpoints, one for each kind of message flow.

Hence he wrote IPC::MicroSocket:
https://metacpan.org/pod/IPC::MicroSocket
o ZMQ: - Perl-ish Interface libzmq - https://metacpan.org/dist/ZMQ o ZMQ::FFI: - Version agnostic Perl bindings for zeromq using ffi - https://metacpan.org/dist/ZMQ-FFI o ZMQ::LibZMQ3: - A libzmq 3.x wrapper for Perl - https://metacpan.org/dist/ZMQ-LibZMQ3
title: ZMQ
